newsitem.title: BELGIUM: NATO backs new Bosnia force plan.
newsitem.headline: NATO backs new Bosnia force plan.

text.p: NATO gave provisional approval on Monday for an alliance-led force of between 25,000-30,000 to stay in Bosnia next year to police the fragile Dayton peace accords, officials said.
They said NATO's 16 ambassadors approved the plan for a Stabilisation Force (SFOR) after meeting representatives of 17 non-NATO nations contributing troops to the peace mission.

NATO foreign ministers, meeting in Brussels on Tuesday and Wednesday, will now give final approval for an 18-month long mission which would officially begin on December 20 -- the day the mandate of the current force expires.
Officials said the United Nations Security Council was expected to pass a resolution approving the force next week.
The new force takes over from the alliance-led Implementation Force (IFOR), which at its height numbered some 60,000 troops from over 30 countries.

Under the plan drawn up by the alliance military, SFOR will be gradually reduced, with formal reviews every six months, until it effectively becomes an "over the horizon" deterrence force located outside Bosnia.
